H0.text: Inertia is a force that keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun.

H1.text: Gravity is the force that keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun.

H2.text: Magnetism is a force that keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun.

H3.text: Solar energy is a force that keeps the planets in orbit around the Sun.

A4.text: Planets orbit the Sun in an ellipse as a consequence of the law of gravity.

A5.text: Kepler viewed the force of the Sun on the planets as magnetic

A6.text: Newton's law of universal gravitation describes gravity as a force by stating that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between their centers of mass.

A7.text: In Einstein's theory, energy and momentum distort spacetime in their vicinity, and other particles move in trajectories determined by the geometry of spacetime.

A8.text: Gravity becomes the most significant interaction between objects at the scale of astronomical bodies, and it determines the motion of satellites, planets, stars, galaxies, and even light.

A9.text: By Borelli's time the concept of inertia had its modern meaning as the tendency of objects to remain in uniform motion and he viewed the Sun as just another heavenly body.
